title: Part 1
content:
Part 1

IN A PREPARED private room, Kamogawa sat in the lower seat, his eyes fixed only on the sake in front of him.

"Sorry to keep you waiting."

"No, let's get started right away."

"Don't drink the sake."

"E-Eh? But there's delicious-looking sake right in front of me. What is this brand? I've never seen it in a pub."

"Are you planning to send off Naoe-sensei with the smell of alcohol? This is nothing more than a formality. Carelessly reaching for it brings no benefit."

"That's..."

In a dazzling high-class ryoutei, being told not to drink sake with a meal right in front of him would feel like torture, but I had no intention of blaming him.

In fact, I too had almost succumbed to temptation several times in the past.

Fortunately, at that time, the person who was taking care of me started drinking alcohol, and I witnessed the moment he was reprimanded and erased because of it, which led to my current abstinence. Those in power drink while taking pleasure in watching the people below them suffer—or so I came to think.

It wasn't just the underling politicians. They looked down on the citizens themselves.

They were always intoxicated with the satisfaction of their desire to conquer, ruling with the rules they created.

"Ayanokouji-sensei, there's something I've been wondering about..."

He really is talkative.

"Why do you always sit in seiza[1]? You can relax your posture at least in this seat."

"It's a habit. In front of Naoe-sensei and the others, I have to sit in seiza for hours without any trouble. I need to get used to it normally, so I won't have issues when it's necessary."

I wasn't even allowed to ask if I could relax my legs.

I had no choice but to continue sitting in seiza until my legs necrotized.

"That's tough..."

Apparently not confident, Kamogawa hastily rearranges himself into seiza.

Even a single small egg tofu served on a small plate would cost four digits if ordered by itself.

However, there was no need to be grateful. I grabbed the small plate roughly and swallowed it without even chewing.

"What a waste…!"

I continued eating, ignoring most of the nonsense Kamogawa kept telling me.

I wasn't interested in whether it was luxurious, had a beautiful appearance, or what kind of dish it was.

As long as I could consume enough energy to keep moving afterward, that was enough.

"I'm going to the restroom."

I briefly excused myself to Kamogawa, stood up with slightly numb legs, and left the room.

After using the restroom and heading back to the private room where Kamogawa was waiting, I spotted the backs of men in suits. Among them was a man who distinctly stood out.

However, I only saw him for a moment, and he disappeared around the corner at the end of the hallway.

"Was that…?"

I felt the urge to follow and confirm his identity, but I restrained myself.

However, that silhouette was definitely Kijima-sensei. Although a minority, he belonged to the Citizens' Party's fourth faction, unaligned with the other three major factions belonging to Naoe-sensei, Isomaru-sensei, and Prime Minister Miyako.

He was the most promising figure among the younger generation and was touted as being closest to becoming the prime minister.

It was impossible to call his presence at the same ryoutei a mere coincidence.

Normally, the ryoutei would coordinate discreetly to avoid such clumsy overlaps.

Is Naoe-sensei already starting to make moves toward the next election?

  1. [1]: Seiza is a formal, traditional Japanese kneeling position that requires the individual to sit on their feet.
